title: The Homelessness Empathy Experience (CDCW)
headline: Homeless people are not defined by their circumstances. This VR experience explains the systemic issues that leads to homelessness and can be used as a tool to increase funding for the CDCW.
inspiration: We're all guilty of it-when we're rushing down the street and a homeless person starts asking for money, you simply ignore them and move on. A person who is homeless is much more than their circumstances, and should be treated as a person. There needs to be more empathy involved with the homeless. One does not simply become homeless because they're lazy, can't hold a job, etc. These issues need to be thrown out and we need to address the systemic issues that lead to homelessness.
what_it_does: Our virtual reality experience allows a person who has had the privilege of a roof over their heads for their whole life to feel what it's like to be homeless. We are aiming to bridge the gap between homelessness and empathy. Users are able to go into the first room, which shows some of the hardships that one faces before they become homeless. Room 2 shows what it is like to be living without a home.
how_we_built_it: Using Unity and C#, we built this Virtual Reality Experience.
accomplishments: We are super proud that we were able to create an entire VR experience in 48 hours. We are also excited for the ways that this can be implemented.
whats_next: This project will be shown to the CDCW and will be used for a variety of purposes. It can be used to raise funds, as it can be a way to show granters what homeless is really like. It will also be used to jumpstart the forthcoming social media revamp and as a way for new volunteers to the shelter to better connect with their work.

title: Circles: Media Engagement Hack-Waltham Partnership for Youth
headline: We designed a specialized media engagement platform, Circles, to bridge the gap between the youth and Waltham Partnership for Youth staff as well as urge students to expand their circle of influence.
inspiration: When we were brainstorming, we talked about how we wanted to partner with Waltham Youth Partnership because of the plethora of opportunities and internships they provide to fight against inequalities and inequities. As a team of diverse students who know the struggles of finding internships and opportunities, we personally related to WYP’s mission and wanted to help improve their presence and communication. We created the online, media engagement platform, Circles, to allow students to get connected without feeling like they are being held back by social barriers as well as enable access to opportunities for Waltham's youth.
what_it_does: Circles targets the exposure of WYP online presence, external communication, and connecting youth to resources. Users are able to make a profile, share their personal circles of interest, and connect to staff, program leaders, and other students through an online forum. This will serve as a way for students to build their network and learn more about volunteer opportunities and educational internships.
how_we_built_it: We communicated to the Board Fellow of WYP, Markia Neufville, to ask her about impeding improvements and issues they want to address with their WYP website. We have built the website for Circles using Html, CSS, SCSS, Dango, and Javascript to strengthen communication between the youth and staff in an interactive manner as well as urge students to expand their circle of influence.
challenges: Our biggest challenge was narrowing down a broad list of ideas we wanted to do. Partnering with WYP inspired us to think about the biggest problems that students often face and, therefore, we had many goals on our list that we wanted to achieve. Through the brainstorming process, we learned more about practicality, compromises, and time management. Another big challenge, we faced was developing the forum and messaging platform. However, with time, patience, and drive, this was accomplished.
accomplishments: We are proud of our team for being motivated to help social good and overturning the little stumbling blocks we faced throughout this hackathon. This was our first hackathon, so there were new challenges we have faced from learning how to participate in one in general and how it works. Building a website in two days is an accomplishment itself! So we are proud to come together for a cause, brainstorm new ideas, and build a method and a website to improve the presence of our nonprofit.
lessons: We learned that working as a team towards a common goal makes anything possible - even within 2 days! We learned about the importance of time management, planning, and task delegation.

title: Clipper Ship Foundation
headline: An Algorithm to detect how well the person is doing
inspiration: The team is passionate about writing a brand-new algorithm to detect a person's wellbing
how_we_built_it: Coding in Java, metrics based on OECD

title: CMe: Connect, Communicate, and Create
headline: Members of OFI love making friends, but there is no way for them to meet others outside of OFI Waltham. CMe leverages the Arc network so they can connect, communicate, & create with their communities.
inspiration: A few of our team members are on sports teams and have team impact players, who are members of I.D.D communities. These impact players get to be a part of the sports teams by going to practices, watching games, and even having a headshot on the rosters. Outside of this, the impact players love to message the Brandeis Athletes constantly on social media, but the athletes are too busy with sports and school to fully engage with them on a daily basis. Through this experience as well as speaking with Joanne Raymond, Director of Marketing and Development at OFI, our team decided to design an app that would address this gap of no social networking platforms for members of the I.D.D. communities.
what_it_does: CMe is an app where members of OFI and the Arc can connect, communicate, and create with people they identify with. CMe will allow OFI members to go beyond their Waltham program and access to members of over 600 other Arc locations. This app is not only safer than other forms of social media, but it is curated just for them.
how_we_built_it: We mainly used Figma for sketching out the wireframe of our app. We also used Animaker to create our videos with an animation effect.
challenges: Lack of time is the biggest challenge that we came across. Although the ultimate goal would be to develop an app, we decided to use wireframe to showcase the layout and functionalities of our app due to the 48-hour time constraint.
accomplishments: We are proud that we managed to create a good visualization of our plans and come up with a way for members of OFI to connect and communicate with people with similar life experiences and interests, which they wouldn’t be able to do in the past.
lessons: We learned how to split up the work efficiently within our team. We worked together on building up the conceptual model, and while Jolie and Sabrina focused on creating the narratives of the story and making the pitch video, Jared and Ellen designed the wireframe. We also developed new skills and learned to use tools like Figma and Animaker.

title: MassIPL
headline: Project focused on a website redesign to help MassIPL reposition itself towards a broader audience.
inspiration: Through conversation with the leaders at MassIPL, we learned that the organization is looking for more effective ways to increase the outreach of its energy-saving program to attract a more diverse pool of faith-based communities and individuals who care about climate justice. It also strives to be a thought leader in educating the faith-based communities on the necessity and benefits of reducing their carbon footprint. However, its current positioning makes the organization looks like a religious organization that serves a relatively exclusive group of houses of worship, which puts constraints on its ability to increase member diversity and gain access to funding channels. We quickly realized that these challenges present opportunities. We created a brand new website that showcases their unique secular position and an effective tool, the environmental stewardship calculator, that will drastically increase member engagements.
how_we_built_it:
MassIPL’s new website was created on Weebly. The design process started in Figma before we brought it to life through our development process. 
For the front-end of the new website, we build the main body of the website with the help of Weebly’s design capabilities. We then created links in between web pages to realize the design flow and make sure it is convenient and clear to the users. For the calculator, we built an algorithm that returns results based on the different variables.
challenges: It took us some time to figure out the correct logic behind the website design. Our goal was to make the website as easy to use as possible while getting our message across. The process of creating the calculator and incorporating it into the website was also a challenge as none of us had previous experience. The purpose of the calculator is to increase user engagement, so we wanted to make sure the questions we ask can do exactly that. Moreover, we were careful about finding the right balance between getting our image across as a secular organization and the fact that we are providing services to faith-based organizations.
accomplishments:
We are glad that we built a fresh website whose purpose and content complement the existing website well. It helps the organization to promote its secular image and brings in traffic from not only houses of worship, but also individuals who care about climate justice in general. 
We wanted to simplify facing the issue MassIPL addresses. The calculator was a key component is doing this because successfully tackling energy inefficiency can seem like a difficult mountain to climb but by basing our suggestions around each unique situation, houses of worship will be able to take incremental steps leading to substantial and sustainable impact which is our goal!
lessons:
This is our first time working with Weebly to create a website. As with any new program, there was a steep learning curve, made more difficult by the short time period. Additionally, after Larry Goldberg's inspiring Keynote, we were prompted to explore how we could make our design as ADA compliant as possible and while this hack may not have been “Born Accessible”, a majority of the design components had been completed beforehand, edits were made prior to the implementation. 
Additionally, for half our team, this was the first time hearing about MassIPL and the bigger movement combating energy inefficiency. So we prioritized taking the time to educate ourselves about the connection between faith-based organizations and climate change and the different ways they can make an impact.
whats_next: MassIPL will continue to do outreach to educate more and more houses of worship on their duties to protect the earth and help them one step at a time. We see MassIPL capable of wielding the power and support from faith-based communities to demand meaningful and impactful social and political changes.

title: Land's Sake Farm - Rebranding to Increase Awareness & Impact
headline: Land's Sake has an acute branding problem, resulting in people being largely unaware of the full scope of their work. Our solution creates a simple, elegant homepage and a stamp to engage customers.

title: Charles River Museum Scavenger Hunt Map
headline: An interactive map that orients visitors around the museum.
inspiration: The Charles River Museum will reopen in April and the staff are trying to promote it as much as possible. Since the museum is difficult to find if you don't know the location well (even Google Maps doesn't lead you straight there!), we decided to turn this disadvantage into an attraction to tourists by integrating a scavenger hunt game with the map.
what_it_does: Our webpage contains a new map (a modified version of an older map) with directions for getting to the museum as well as the floorplan for the museum. Visitors can scan the QR code that will be posted at nearby parking lots and local businesses or at the museum entrance itself to get the map of the surrounding area with clear directions on how to get to the museum, as well as maps that show how to navigate both floors of the museum. By scanning QR codes placed throughout the museum in different exhibits, visitors will be able to access information about the exhibits on their phones and get a chance to find "easter eggs"! Prizes will be awarded to those who successfully complete the scavenger hunt; these prizes will be small gifts like movie tickets and restaurant coupons donated by local businesses in exchange for promotion at the museum. We believe this collaboration with local businesses, especially other non-profits in the area, will promote mutually beneficial business within the community and will lead to future collaborations that could include co-hosting cultural events at the museum and/or more cross-promotional advertising between businesses with which we form partnerships. The map we created also highlights a few other local businesses to use as landmarks for finding the museum; this map could be redesigned in the future to be even more detailed and include more businesses.
how_we_built_it: We based our interactive page on the Ruby on Rails framework and the static page using Webflow. We also imported a QR code generator, but it's up to the museum to decide whether they want to use a separate QR code generator or a built-in generator. We also made use of the websites freeonlinsurveys.com and wheelofnames.com to create our scavenger hunt quiz and wheel of fortune to generate randomized prizes.
challenges: In the beginning, we had trouble figuring out how to create an easy-to-navigate map since even Google Maps was not accurate in locating the museum and how to get to its entrance. We decided to use QR codes to show visitors a simple map with clear walkways to the museum and QR codes within the museum to link users to different exhibits that would help them complete the scavenger hunt we created. Through this simplification of the map, we were able to achieve basic approximate user orientation while avoiding the technical difficulty of GPS location.
accomplishments:
We were able to implement a website prototype within one day, and the website dynamic is such that museum's staff can change the map or edit exhibit information in the future. As a result, our product is easy to maintain, even for a crew who knows nothing about coding.
We also developed a marketing plan to collaborate with many local businesses in Waltham that we hope will benefit the entire local community along with the museum.
lessons: We have gained much experience from building the website, including designing the UI and designing and implementing the database. We also had a great discussion with museum staff and mentors at the hackathon to learn about developing market proposals. We learned about how to run a non-profit organization and tried to explore the possibility of the operation of a social enterprise.
whats_next:
The website UI is rather rudimentary right now. It needs to be upgraded to be even more user-friendly in the future, and it would be great if we could connect it with the museum's Virtual Matterport (the virtual reality version of the museum) in a more integrated way instead of by directing users only to links to this. 
It is also necessary to start reaching out to local restaurants and businesses near the museum to form partnerships and sponsorships.

title: CRM's Almost Forgotten Immigrant Inventors Exhibit
headline: An interactive online exhibit that creates an immersive experience for high school visitors using virtual reality, an inventor map, quizzes, and bios of those inventors who are almost forgotten.
inspiration: Everyone knows the names of the great inventors: Thomas Edison, Alexander Graham Bell, and even Steve Jobs. They invented products that changed our everyday life and were rewarded handsomely for it. Their inventions brought them great financial success.However, not all inventors were that lucky. There are many stories of inventors whose inventions are an integral part of our daily life, but they either never received the recognition they deserved or failed to profit from the success of their inventions. Even more so, we celebrate Almost Forgotten Immigrant Inventors who have contributed their life's work and benefit our society while working and studying in the United States of America.
what_it_does: We are most proud of our immersive experience through our website wherein we will be able to engage with the future of our nation and encourage them to pursue a career in creative solutions. We encourage that through our immersive AR/VR online exhibition.
how_we_built_it: We developed the site using Google Sites. The VR 3D model is built using Blender.
lessons:
We learned not to be such perfectionists and work together as a team.
Don't give up and it is perfectly fine to ask for help.
whats_next: Adding more features and expanding the exhibits. Expand the number of AFI on the sites and their biographies. Add some new problems that students can think about.

title: Leland Home Hack
headline: Our project makes an application for employees to update their daily reports and a dashboard for employers to keep track of employees' working status
inspiration: The hack inspired us that we can do so much more than we can imagine
what_it_does: The APP allows employees to register into the database of Leland and upload their daily report through the APP. The information can be processed and then displayed on the dashboard.
how_we_built_it: We built it using Jotform platform. The APP consists of muiltiple online forms that can be updated and compile into the system of Leland Home
challenges: There are many constraints in the elder care industry. Instead of focusing on how “clients” who are aged 60-102 can benefit from technology, we decided it’s more efficient to introduce technology to care givers who are more technology savvy.
accomplishments: None of us have participated in any Hackathons before. It’s was amazing how our bonded over the last 48 hours and teach ourselves technology concepts.
lessons: We learned how to use Jotform to build an APP and also how to work in teams in an effective way
whats_next: The hack can be refined. As for our team, next step is a good night of sleep and a fun board game.

title: HOPE Worldwide Rebranding
headline: Full rebrand for the organization HOPE Worldwide
inspiration: We were inspired by HOPE worldwide's mission and wanted to fully embody this through our rebranding. As for visual inspiration, we took inspiration from the websites of similar non-profit organizations, such as 4oceans.
what_it_does: So how did we rebrand Hope Worldwide? We crafted a unique logo for them, which is essential for any organization to have. Logos are the face of the organization because organizations may have similar names, but a logo will help any organization stand out from the rest.What else must an organization have to build their brand? In the digital age, a website. Websites are essentially the digital resume of the organization. Any resume must be organized, easy on the eyes, and concisely packed with information, and the same applies with websites.
how_we_built_it: We made the logo based on the current color theme and the mission of the website, with some adjustments to better suit the organization as a whole. We then organized all of the info that is currently on their website, grouping similar elements together in their own webpages. Lastly, we conveyed this visually through the use of Figma.
challenges: Our biggest challenge was concisely organizing the load of information the site had - particularly on the homepage. We found that there was too much info on the homepage, so much that it doesn't compel users to look at the other pages in the website. With our new website organization, though, we believe that our formatting will help retain others' interest in both the website and its associated organization.
accomplishments: We're particularly proud of the logo and organization of the site, because of how effectively they work together.
lessons: We learned the need to prioritize aspects that make a successful marketing plan. Additionally, this project emphasized to us the importance of logos and avoiding visual overload on a website. Lastly, we learned how to incorporate user experience into marketing strategies.
whats_next: We plan to implement our new website design and see the impact is has on the site's visitors (retention and click-through rates). Additionally, we want to further develop the organization of the site to make good use of the screen's space and user experience.

title: MedPromatic
headline: A one-stop shop for all medical needs

title: HeatSmart Alliance Digitization of Customer Journey
headline: CRM Portal
inspiration: We were inspired by HeatSmart Alliance’s mission to tangibly reduce greenhouse gas emissions by helping MA residents choose the best heat pump installation and by the dedication and expertise of the HSA volunteer coaches and staff. At the current state, HeatSmart Alliance coaches currently rely on collecting customer information via email correspondence and the organization’s digital presence is minimal. We hope to offer a digital platform that can benefit the organization to help increase its outreach in the future and capture valuable data on the heating cooling landscape in MA.
what_it_does: The HSA portal was created to be a customer relationship management (CRM) tool that eliminates the manual administrative steps of collecting data, so coaches can focus more on educating and coaching customers. MA 2030 Clean Energy & Climate Plan calls for 1M heat pumps by 2030. The result of digitizing these processes will help free up each coach’s time and in turn, help expand their reach to accelerate the adoption of energy-efficient heat pumps in MA homes and buildings.
how_we_built_it: We created a mockup on Figma to lay out the web pages and their connections to each other. Afterward, we used EditorX to create the website.
challenges: HeatSmart Alliance currently utilizes WordPress for its main website. For this project, we decided to go with the no-code approach due to the learning curve required with WordPress. We used Wix’s Editor X, a web development service. While using the platform, we ran into some roadblocks that required a paid subscription to the service. This included giving custom login information, assigning roles, and building a separate private messaging system.
accomplishments: The team is most proud of our accomplishments with functional buttons, creating a complete webpage flowchart, our presentation, our submenu and menu bar, the ability to upload files, and adding a “leave a rating” feature.
lessons: Many of our team members were new to web design and development. We learned to use Figma to create a website mockup and create a website with EditorX. We learned how to add a feature to upload files, design menu and submenu bars, and create coach and client-only pages.

title: WPY External Rebranding
headline: WPY has a trememdous impact but struggles to communicate their value propositions to the public. We revemp the old website to improve user experience so that it can atttract more future donors.
inspiration: ```The Waltham Partnership for Youth’s mission is to cultivate today’s students into tomorrow’s leaders. We accomplish this by developing programs and building a syndicate working together to support our youth. We are strong, but like other organizations, we have pain points. As a group we believed that one of the most valuable tools of engagement and awareness is having an effective platform to communicate. Our team conducted a survey and census that showed that the current website lacks engagement and struggles to communicate WPY’s value to the youth and community. Taking a look at their current website, we see the design and fonts are outdated. Starting with the home page, and even then the get involved page which provides no additional information to donors other than a donate button and an address.
how_we_built_it: ```We first did a user research collecting feedbacks on what the viewers like and dislike about the website, focusing on the organization of the menu bar, information density on each page, and what would they care about if they are potential donors looking for ways to contribute. Then, using Google Sites, we completely revamped the website with a fresh look, better segmented pages, more visually appealing color schemes, improved logo presentation, and most importantly, collection of crucial information that the donors care about all in one place.
accomplishments: ```We’re proud of designing a website that WPY can implement and use to advance their current operations. The organization provides a multitude of resources to the community, and that often gets lost in translation. We’re happy to have created a design that more effectively communicates WPY’s values to the community. We’re also really proud of how well we were able to work and generate ideas as a team.

title: A Friendly Navigator
headline: The Leland Home is a non-profit cause with a simple message to help people. However, the site is hard to navigate for their target audience. Implementing a simple bot to help the user is the solution!

title: Hope Worldwide Challenges
headline: We came out with some suggestions towards three challenges Hope Worldwide Boston has been facing. Hopefully our ideas could inspire the team of HWW Boston.
inspiration: We got the inspiration for the sentiment analysis part from the course we took last semester. For the other theoretical parts, we were inspired by readings and the data we collected.
how_we_built_it: We design a google form survey asking the recipients to fill it out after participating in each event. There are a total of 4 types of questions to qualify recipients' experience, degree of satisfaction, how many times participating events, the intention of sharing and participating in other events.We also design word clouds and conduct sentiment analysis based on comments and ratings from google form questionnaires and social media.
challenges: It’s hard for us to get real responses from people who attended our events in the past. Thus, we simulated responses and conducted sentiment analysis.
accomplishments: By collecting the information of population structure and reading through the annual report of the overall organization, we filtered useful information and made decisions based on them. Within a short time we worked out with code that can help us to do the sentiment analysis.
lessons: We learned how to brainstorm marketing strategies and analyze comments for NGOs.

title: The Nexus Project by WCOC - Nexus Connection
headline: This website helps nonprofits and for-profits to connect; businesses can quickly learn about nonprofits and connect to them through a forum, while nonprofits can easily communicate their needs.
inspiration: We were passionate about the idea of being able to create long-lasting and impactful relationships between local nonprofits and for-profits. We came up with a creative and effective solution that would connect these organizations through a website that could match nonprofits and for-profits together and create a line of communication. The website structure is inspired by dating applications because of the efficient way they allow people to meet to easily create a line of communication through one swipe.
what_it_does: This website allows businesses to discover non-profits that align with their passions and values. After finding nonprofits that interest them, the business will be allowed to join the forum designated to that non-profit where nonprofits can communicate their needs and businesses can communicate back stating if they can fulfill their requests.
how_we_built_it: We created this website from scratch using a MERN stack (sans MongoDB due to time constraints) with Typescript. Backend development involved creating a structure of API routes, functions, and data structures for storing for-profits, non-profits, and forum logs. It was accomplished through Express and Node.js. Front-end development was done through a React app, using libraries such as Material-UI and react-router-dom.This project was written with Typescript, React, Material-UI, NodeJS, Express, and GitHub.
challenges: This project had a significant amount of technical coding involved. Due to time constraints, we were unable to fully implement some features we had envisioned, such as storing our database on MongoDB and a matching algorithm. A good amount of time was spent debugging and researching different packages, functions, and implementations that would best suit our needs.
accomplishments: We were given an issue (how to connect for-profits and nonprofits?) and we brainstormed, planned, and coded our way into the product we present here. We’re pretty proud of this.
lessons: Our team is composed of a diverse background of skills. Some of us learned about full stack development and the variety of packages, languages, and platforms that come with this programming. Some of us learned GitHub collaboration and how to pitch an engaging proposal. All of us learned what we can accomplish in 48 hours with a little (lot) of caffeine.
whats_next: We would like to create a matching algorithm that will refine user preferences by taking into account any filters the user chooses (i.e. nonprofits within a 10 mile radius, nonprofits in the “Research and Education” category) and the types of non-profits the user swipes left or right on. Our goal is to build an algorithm that will most efficiently align nonprofits with businesses’ values, passions, and missions.We would like to polish up the GUI aesthetically and functionally. Next steps include allowing non-profits to edit their own profile and forum posts, and allowing businesses to select preferred non-profit categories.We hope to connect the WCOC membership database with our user and non-profit database. This will allow non-profit WCOC members to automatically have a profile in the Nexus Connection, and allow for-profit WCOC members to gain access to this application. To help with security, we would like to create a login screen, where members of the chamber can login to access this networking program.

title: Stay The Night
headline: We made a website that streamlines the process of finding available beds for homeless people, and connecting them to relevant resources such as food, self-care, rehabilitation, and transport.

title: improve customer experience of the leland home
headline: research the customer experience and website information of the leland home, provide solutions of improving the customer experience
inspiration: What inspired our project was that improve safer, simpler, and affordable services for persons age 62 and over who desire or need assistance in their daily living during the special years with Covid-19. On the other hand, by our designed customer journey mapping and the whole solution, we also inspired that we optimize and improve the customer experience for the LELAND HOME to offered seniors comfortable accommodations, personalized services and have a variety of games and activities, which are looking forward to making seniors’ life happy.
what_it_does:
According to the collected information and demands which can represent the characters and real demand for seniors (old than 62), we designed the customer journey mapping, also provide the whole solution to help seniors.
Firstly, the customer journey mapping to Rich website information, so that users directly intuitive experience the whole process, we can find out possible problems with the Leland Home website so as to improve customer service.
Our customer can use this map to get the service she needs. She meets the first touchpoints
And her action is separated into two categories at this touchpoint.
One is that she keeps browsing the Leland website for more information but some of these sections are blank, the other is redirected to the website of Deaconess Abundant Life Services which has more information she is looking for.
how_we_built_it:
Firstly， we try our best to collect the information and feedback from some seniors. And then we analyze the current website of the LELAND HOME and the characteristic of seniors. 
Secondly, we discussed and designed the customer journey mapping, including guiding the entire process, customer sentiment analysis, and detecting the pain point of the customer searching experience.
Next, based on our designed mapping, we provide the solution, which has voice service, different language choices, and translation tools.
challenges: Time management and Covid-19 were our biggest challenges. During 48-hours, we didn’t have enough time for finding more information and demand from customers who are more than 62 years old. On the other hand, due to Covid-19, we didn’t visit some customers and get the feedback face to face, which we think is helpful for collecting information and demand from customers.
accomplishments: We are proud of the design and solution of the customer journey mapping which can be helpful to improve the customer experience of the LELAND HOME. We are proud that our solution can optimize and improve the customer experience and help the seniors (old than 62), which can make them happier and healthier. We are also proud of our collaboration which makes us complete this project successfully and efficiently. Team work and a group project with discussion, divide up, collaboration, are so amazing.
lessons:
We learned many new things about customer journey mapping design and process. We learned that focus on the characteristics and real demands of seniors (old than 62) and learned to customize the design of the journey mapping.
On the other hand, we all tried to learn how to collaborate and how to divide up work for completing this project effectively and efficiently. We also improve our skills in PPT、journey mapping design, research, thinking, etc.

title: The Bag
headline: "The Bag" is a money budgeting platform geared towards high school students to encourage them to start saving money by visualizing the allocation of their money toward their goals aka "their bags".
inspiration: Our Inspiration for this project is many high school students in the US don't learn about financial literacy and things like credit card, credit scores, etc. Not knowing these tools can put these students at a disadvantage later in their lives and a very important aspect of adult life. Many people in our group also experience these lack of resources in college and are now behind of things like building credit. We wanted to try and create a bridge to allow students to learn it out of school, but feel incentive to do it.
what_it_does: When logged on users can create "bag", which are objectives that they can start saving money towards, they can allocate a desired amount of money into each fund, they can also create, group bags where they can create a bag with their friends and all allocate money towards a goal, like a big vacation, etc.
how_we_built_it: We built "The Bag" using Figma, a useful application to prototype applications.
challenges: It was a challenge to try and navigate Figma and we ran into many problems, but we watched many tutorials and read multiple articles to get a better understand of the software and we are way more confident in our skills now than before
accomplishments: We're proud of fleshing out our idea into reality and learning about Figma, which is a very useful tool that none of us knew about. We believe that this idea would have big impacts not only in Waltham, but in the world, financial literacy is an important thing everyone should be taught in school and we are happy we can make it engaging for the youth while teaching them how to budget and important financial literacy topics.
lessons: We learned Figma and how to create an interactive prototype, usually we dive straight into coding and make things up on the fly, but this time we took a slow and analytical approach to really plan out our data and flesh it out.
whats_next: Now that we have a fleshed out idea we want to do to high schools around Waltham and select a small group of students and ask for their feedback on the application and apply that feedback to our product and start coding in Flutter to make it a realityMake sure to check out our flow out below!!

title: Hope Worldwide Metrics
headline: We are working on building up metrics for Hope Worldwide, hoping to push the social impact of the organization.
inspiration: We were inspired by the project that Hope Worldwide Massachusetts has been working on, Food Pantry, Saturday Academy, and Elderly programs. However, one obstacle is how to let stakeholders know exactly what contribution has been made by Hope Worldwide? And what outcomes can we see after quantifying the social impact of this organization?
what_it_does: So we came up with the social impact management metrics together with a questionnaire that can be used to collect data, to help Hope worldwide make a better evaluation. It's clear that such metrics will attract not only volunteers, donators, but also enhance the internal administration of Hope Worldwide.
lessons: Acting as consultants, we try to find the demand of an organization. Tough the schedule is really tight, we made some outcomes through our teamwork!
whats_next: After collecting adequate data, we hope analysis of each project can be made through our metrics. And a social impact report can be accomplished in the end, which is attractive to donators, volunteers, and other funders such as the government.

title: AccountUp
headline: Help people from African countries open bank accounts and be financially included into the main stream
inspiration:
Lack of access to bank accounts among the marginalized people of people living in African Countries. Research indicators show that less than a quarter of adults in Africa have an account with a formal
financial institution, and many adults in Africa use informal methods to save (such as Rotating
Savings and Credit Associations (ROSCAs), tontines, chit funds, burial societies) and borrow. Low and volatile income levels, inflationary environments, high illiteracy rates, inadequate infrastructure, governance challenges, and the limited competition within the banking industry as well as the high cost of banking in Africa are some of the factors leading to its underdeveloped financial sector and its limited outreach.
(friends, family, and informal private lenders).
what_it_does: Given certain parameters concerning the user's background,my app tries to predict how easy or difficult it is for the user to open a bank account in an African country
accomplishments: I am proud to present a fully functional web app that uses real data to assist people in knowing why they arent able to open bank accounts
lessons: I learnt many different things during this hackathon. I learnt how to built web app using streamlit and new technologies like ML and predictive modeling
whats_next: Improving the original ML model and deploying it for research purposes

title: Heat Pump Alliance
headline: Promoting the adoption of using Heat Smart Alliance to reduce household carbon footprints
inspiration: Climate change is the term that has been mentioned a lot recently. Because of climate change, warmer temperatures over time are changing weather patterns and disrupting the usual balance of nature. This poses many risks to human beings and all other forms of life on Earth. The causes for climate change are because of pollution, carbon emission, green house gas emission, etc. With the thought to reduce the amount of carbon and green house gas emission to save the earth, we would like to help Heat Smart Alliance to reach to more people and speed up their work through developing technology aided coaching, digitalization of existing customer journey, and expand the reach to more MA communities.

title: Nurture
headline: Automated Artificial Environment Chamber
inspiration: The fondness towards gardening and plant growth in artificial environment or similar like poultry incubator was a major motivation behind our idea of building Nurture. We wanted to build a feasible and versatile solution with a comparatively easier user interface that can be used by everyone and not only laboratories or industries.
how_we_built_it: Here we are showing nurture to monitor the parameters for a plant that will produce artificially controlled environments crucial for its growth and seed germination in any environment. We used MQTT for the messaging part and we used motor pump to automatically water the plant and a bulb to warm the environment. Used an ESP32 to connect to the WiFi and ran RTOS on it to run the functions.

title: Corporate Social Responsibility In-Kind Database
headline: Our team created a dynamic database for the Haven Project with over 40 resources for in-kind donations to diversify value, assets, and increase accessibility to resources.
inspiration: Our team observed that like many other Non-Profit organizations, the Haven Project relies on donations and grants to access the resources needed to serve their mission. Our team wanted to find a way to help Haven access a more diversified set of resources.
what_it_does: The clothing category includes resources for clothing donations, and the toiletries category includes resources for toiletry donations. Auction donations lists companies that will donate high-demand items that can be auctioned by the non-profit for fundraising, and the meals & vouchers include resources for meal vouchers, food donations, and restaurant gift cards. Local grants lists companies that give small grants to nonprofits through the company’s local branches, and job resources lists available resources to assist in building workforce skills or finding apprenticeship opportunities. We believe these categories will help the Haven Project access a plethora of resources to serve their clients.
how_we_built_it: During research, we learned about Corporate Social Responsibility and In-Kind donations. We saw great potential for connecting these resources with the Haven Project. Through Corporate Social Responsibility programs, many large corporations give various types of donations to local nonprofits other than money. We learned that these are called “in-kind donations”. Our team decided we wanted to find a way to make it easy for the Haven Project to access the many in-kind donations that are available. Our team worked on gathering information about over 40 companies that participate in Corporate Social Responsibility programs. We created a database that listed the company names, the type of donations they make, descriptions of the donations, and all necessary steps to apply for and receive the donation. We filtered the donations by type so that the Haven Project can easily select which category of available donations they would like to view. The categories include clothing, meals & vouchers, auction donations, local grants, toiletries, and job resources. We implemented our database into a website using Wix website builder. All information from the database is accessible on the website.
challenges: The largest challenge our team faced occurred when one of our team members exited the group fairly late into the event. This member had the most coding experience, and left us with a complicated and unfinished website. Our team had to ideate a way to build an effective web interface with limited coding skills and limited time. We started the website from scratch, deserting the previous interface we had spent many hours working on. We quickly found creative ways to work with a website builder, and implemented fast research to learn how to transfer our database into the website builder.
accomplishments: All of our determination and willingness to persevere has led us to our finished product. We have created a user-friendly and effective web interface that the Haven Project can use to access all of the resources we spent time researching.
lessons: Through determination, effective team-work, and creative problem solving, daunting challenges can be overcome.
whats_next: Our team intends for this database to continue to be updated and expanded as further research is conducted. In the future, our team envisions a function that would allow donors to visit the database and register their own resource offerings to the database.

title: Digital Marketing for Donor Engagement Hack
headline: We've delivered an easy to implement marketing strategy for The Haven Project that focuses on engaging donors. This marketing strategy focuses on establishing a brand and leveraging impact data.
inspiration: We were heavily inspired about our past experiences in marketing strategies with our team consulting projects which were for the same company. We were able to call back on the skills we gained in data analysis and marketing/brand awareness strategies from that experience.
what_it_does: This hack provides a template and implementable guides on establishing a brand and leveraging impact data.
how_we_built_it: We used Miro to create the guide and Venngage for the dashboard.
lessons: This taught us how to brainstorm in a rapid manner and create a bumper-sticker pitch for an entire plan, which takes a considerable amount of patience and compromising.
whats_next: We hope to take the stamina and skills we built for this Hackathon and use it for similar future ventures. We hope The Haven Project will be able to consider our project as a viable solution.

title: Waltham Rotary Club: Membership Growth Solution
headline: We developed a contest to help solve the Waltham Rotary Club's membership growth. The contests offers students the opportunity to gain project planning experience and connect them with the Rotary Club
what_it_does: Addresses Waltham Rotary Club's struggles with younger membership.
whats_next: The next steps are getting the contest approved so it can happen in the fall!
